text: Seems like even if the cookie is set, the script still sends form submission to HubSpot :confused:
that would be very problematic if that's the case
is it just saving as a draft?
Yeah you're very right, I guess the form submissions HubSpot marks as a user wanting to be tracked
running a couple of tests on my end

Definitely the most sure fire way to do this would be to use the <https://legacydocs.HubSpot.com/docs/methods/forms/advanced_form_options|advanced form options> and after the user clicks submit check if they have the do not track cookie if they do don't submit the form if they don't then submit the form but I feel like there has to be a little bit of an easier way
<@U3T21PDBK> you are suggesting a completely new website build as opposed to evaluating and updating the existing one?

If you are talking about HubSpotâ€™s legacy templates and legacy modules vs themes, then yes.
In my experience it usually costs more to fix old legacy cms sites within that framework. We either sell a new site or recreate it in the 2.0 cms
